snippet: The tabletop mountains near the Amazon rain forest can be isolated, but they support a wide diversity of species that are found nowhere else on the planet.
abstract: Study in journal Evolution reports first DNA-based evidence that the rare and numerous species of animals and plants found in the tepuis, or tabletop mountains, looming over the Amazon rain forest spent millions of years climbing up the colossal cliffs; study focused on tree frogs, which does not rule out a 'lost world' hypothesis for other species mysteriously surviving in the flat mountain top areas.
lead_paragraph: The tabletop mountains near the Amazon rain forest can be isolated, but they support a wide diversity of species that are found nowhere else on the planet.

headline.seo: It’s Not So Lonely at the Top: Tepui Ecosystems Thrive Up High
headline.main: It’s Not So Lonely at the Top: Ecosystems Thrive High in the Sky
headline.print_headline: It’s Not So Lonely at the Top: Ecosystems Thrive High in the Sky
